questions.text: Identify the condition from the plain radiograph of the biliary tree
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Porcelain Gallbladder The image shows a Porcelain gallbladder . Plain radiographs: A plain X-ray may also show rare cases of calcification of the gallbladder, a so-called porcelain gallbladder . This is more commonly seen in computed tomography (CT). Traditionally, this has been considered an indication of cholecystectomy as it was associated with a high incidence of gallbladder carcinoma . However, contemporary data suggest that this may not be the case, with the true incidence of cancer being less than 5%. Therefore, decisions on whether or not a cholecystectomy should be performed should be individualised depending on the age of the patient, comorbidities and presence or absence of symptoms.

Highyeild:

Porcelain Gallbladder Porcelain Gallbladder is characterized by extensive calcium encrustation of the gallbladder wall. The condition is caused by chronic inflammation of the gallbladder . Porcelain Gallbladder is usually associated with gallstones and is typically detected incidentally on plain abdominal radiographs, sonograms, or CT images. Most patients with Porcelain Gallbladder are asymptomatic , and the mean age of diagnosis is 54 years. There is a 6% incidence of carcinoma development in Porcelain Gallbladder cases. Surgery should not be delayed, even if the patient is asymptomatic, as the occurrence of carcinoma is remarkably high.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. If, a plain radiograph of the gallbladder will show radiopaque gallstones in 10% of patients. Rarely, the centre of a stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure and this gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on a radiograph: the ‘ Mercedes–Benz ’ or ‘ seagull sign’ . Option: C. Gas may be seen in the wall of the gallbladder (emphysematous cholecystitis). Gas in the biliary tree may also be seen normally after endoscopic sphincterotomy or following a surgical anastomosis. Plain radiograph showing radiopaque stones in the gall- bladder. Radiopaque stones are rare (1096). Computed tomography scan demonstrating callcifica tion in the gallbladder wall ('porcelain gallbladder').

Extraedge:

Plain radiographic findings can be used for the diagnosis of Porcelain Gallbladder, but a CT scan can confirm the diagnosis if there is any doubt. Cholecystectomy is recommended for all patients diagnosed with Porcelain Gallbladder, regardless of symptoms.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the following Cholecystogram
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diverticulosis of Gallbladder Cholecystogram showing diverticulosis with dots of contrast medium in the gallbladder wall. Diverticulosis of the gallbladder is usually manifest as black pigment stones impacted in the outpouchings of the lacunae of Luschka. Diverticulosis of the gallbladder may be demonstrated by cholecystography, especially when the gallbladder contracts after a fatty meal. There are small dots of contrast medium just within and outside the gallbladder. A septum may also be present, to be distinguished from the Phrygian cap. The treatment is cholecystectomy.

Highyeild:

Diverticulosis of the gallbladder is characterized by black pigment stones impacted in the outpouchings of the lacunae of Luschka. Cholecystography can be used to visualize this condition, particularly after the gallbladder contracts following the consumption of a fatty meal. Contrast medium appears as small dots within and outside of the gallbladder wall in cholecystography. Treatment for diverticulosis of the gallbladder involves the surgical removal of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A & D. Strawberry bladder is seen in cholesterolosis {Deposition of cholesterol crystals in the wall of the gallbladder.}

questions.text: Identify the type of Bismuth-corlette classification for cholangiocarcinoma
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type II The anatomical extent of the disease is classified according to either the Bismuth–Corette or Memorial Sloan–Kettering Cancer Centre Classification.

Highyeild:

Bismuth-corlette classification for cholangiocarcinoma The anatomical extent of hilar cholangiocarcinoma can be classified using the Bismuth-Corlette or MSKCC classification. MSKCC classification has three T-stage criteria for hilar cholangiocarcinoma: T1, T2, and T3. T1 refers to a tumour involving the biliary confluence without extension to second-order biliary radicles. T2 refers to a tumour involving the biliary confluence with unilateral extension to second-order biliary radicles and ipsilateral portal vein involvement or ipsilateral hepatic atrophy. T3 refers to a tumour involving the biliary confluence with bilateral extension to second-order biliary radicles or unilateral extension to second-order biliary radicles with contralateral portal vein involvement or contralateral hepatic lobar atrophy, or main or bilateral portal venous involvement.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B, C & D.

Extraedge:

Surgical resection is suitable for 10-15% of patients with complete resection as the aim. Respectability depends on patient and tumour factors. Surgery involves standard or extended hepatic resection, caudate lobe excision, en bloc lymphadenectomy, and biliary tree reconstruction .

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent abdominal pain for the past month. The patient reports that the pain is located in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen and that it does not change with food intake. She has had no nausea, vomiting, or change in weight. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She does not smoke. Physical examination shows a small, firm mass in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown. This patient's condition puts her at increased risk of developing which of the following
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gall bladder Carcinoma This patient’s abdominal CT scan shows an opaque lesion in the right upper quadrant suggestive of gall bladder calcification. This is also referred to as porcelain gall bladder.While the exact pathophysiology of porcelain gallbladder is unknown, it is associated with cholelithiasis and chronic gallbladder inflammation. It is often identified incidentally on abdominal imaging, although it may present with right upper quadrant pain, as in this patient. There is a small but significant risk of developing gallbladder adenocarcinoma, so the recommended treatment is cholecystectomy.

Highyeild:

Carcinoma Gallbladde r has the highest incidence in India and Pakistan . It is more common in women in their 6th and 7th decade. 75-98% of all patients with CA GB have cholelithiasis , indicating a strong correlation between the two. The incidence of CA GB in a population of patients with gallstones ranges from 3-3% , highlighting the importance of early detection. CA GB is an aggressive malignancy with a poor prognosis , making it a significant challenge to manage. The most common gene mutation in CA GB is p53, followed by K-ras and BRAF. The most common mode of CA GB spread is a direct invasion into adjacent organs. The most common site of CA GB is the fundus (60%), followed by the body and neck.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Common risk factors for bowel obstruction include prior abdominal surgery (resulting in scarring and bowel adhesions), malignancy, strictures, gallstone ileus, and incarcerated hernias. This patient does not have any history of these risk factors. Porcelain gallbladder is not associated with bowel obstruction. Option: C. Gallbladder perforation is a potential complication of cholelithiasis and cholecystitis. While both cholelithiasis and cholecystitis can also present with intermittent RUQ pain, another answer option more directly addresses the major risk of porcelain gallbladder. Option: D. The two greatest risk factors for pancreatic cancer are smoking and chronic pancreatitis. CT is generally the initial imaging modality used for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis, and classic findings include pancreatic atrophy, ductal dilatation, calcification, and/or pseudocyst formation, none of which is seen here. Porcelain gallbladder is not a risk factor for pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

Extraedge:

The Nevin classification is used for staging CA GB to guide treatment. Calcified GB is associated with cancer in 10% of cases, suggesting that calcification may be an important risk factor. Helicobacter pylori & H. bilis have been demonstrated to increase the risk of CA GB by 6 fold. There is an increased risk of CA GB in FAP & HNPCC.

questions.text: In the image given below the right hepatic artery is seen as tortuous. What it is known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both The most dangerous anomalies are where the hepatic artery takes a tortuous course on the front of the origin of the cystic duct, or the right hepatic artery.is tortuous and the cystic artery is short. The tortuosity is known as the ‘caterpillar turn’ or ‘Moynihan’s hump’ .In such cases, the right hepatic artery can get injured and can lead to haemorrhage during surgery

Highyeild:

The right hepatic artery can have a tortuous appearance with a caterpillar turn or Moynihan's hump. The right hepatic artery is located in close proximity to the gallbladder and the cystic duct and gives off a short cystic artery before branching out. Biliary and ductal anomalies can include a double cystic duct, separate insertion into the duodenum, and anomalous low insertion of the right sectional duct. The posterior sectional duct is usually at a higher risk of injury in cases of anomalous low insertion.

questions.text: What is the type of extrahepatic biliary atresia shown in the picture?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type ll

Highyeild:

Kasai Classification of Biliary Atresia Type I atresia: blockage limited to the CBD Type II atresia: complete blockage of the common hepatic duct Type IIa atresia: patent gallbladder and CBD present Type IIb atresia: gallbladder, cystic duct, and CBD all obstructed Type III atresia: complete obstruction of right and left hepatic ducts and extrahepatic biliary tree

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Type I: atresia restricted to the common bile duct; Option: B. Type II: atresia of the common hepatic duct; Option: C. Type III: atresia of the right and left hepatic ducts.

Extraedge:

Intraoperative cholangiography is the gold standard for diagnosing biliary atresia. While the percutaneous liver biopsy is highly accurate, it cannot provide specific findings for biliary atresia. The preferred treatment for biliary atresia is the Kasai hepatoportoenterostomy, also known as Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. Post-operative cholangitis is the most common complication following Kasai hepatoportoenterostomy.

questions.text: A 1-day-old female child presents with yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera, his stools are pale. On laboratosry examination, his alkaline phosphatase is raised. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extrahepatic biliary atresia Atresia is present in approximately 1 per 12000 live births and affects males and females equally. About one-third of patients are jaundiced at birth. In all, however, jaundice is present by the end of the first week and deepens progressively. Liver function tests show an obstructive pattern with elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase.

Highyeild:

EXTRAHEPATIC BILIARY ATRESIA Biliary atresia is a condition where there is progressive blockage of the extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts. The cause of the condition is unknown , and it occurs in approximately 1 in 12,000 live births. There is currently no medical therapy available to reverse the blockage caused by the condition. Patients who do not undergo the surgical treatment will develop biliary cirrhosis, and portal hypertension , and are likely to die before the age of 2. Biliary atresia is the most common indication for pediatric liver transplantation . The pathologic hallmarks of the disease include bile duct proliferation, severe cholestasis with plugging, and inflammatory cell infiltrate. Over time, these changes progress to fibrosis and end-stage cirrhosis. Neural cell adhesion molecule (CD56) staining is positive in biliary atresia.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. The meconium may be a little bile stained, but later the stools are pale and the urine is dark. (CAROLI’S DISEASE) . This rare congenital condition is characterised by multiple irregular saccular dilatations of the intrahepatic ducts, separated by segments of normal or stenotic ducts, with a normal extrahepatic biliary system. Option: C. Intussusception - it is uncommon in a newborn. Option: D . Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis-symptom starts after 2-3 weeks. Non-bilious Vomiting occurs.

Extraedge:

The preferred treatment for biliary atresia is the Kasai hepatoportoenterostomy, also known as Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. Post-operative cholangitis is the most common complication following Kasai hepatoportoenterostomy.

questions.text: The strawberry gallbladder is seen in
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cholesterosis In the fresh state, the interior of the gallbladder looks something like a strawberry in patients with this condition; the yellow specks (submucous aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters) correspond to the seeds . It may be associated with cholesterol stones.

Highyeild:

Cholesterolosis is a condition where lipids accumulate in the mucosa of the gallbladder wall. This results in nodules that are less than 1mm in diameter in about two-thirds of cases, giving the mucosa a coarse and granular appearance. In the remaining one-third of cases, the nodules are larger and polypoid in appearance ( polypoid form ). The accumulation of lipids creates yellow deposits on a background of hyperemic mucosa, known as "strawberry gallbladder ." Cholesterolosis may be associated with the formation of cholesterol stones.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Cholesterol polyposis of the gallbladder Ultrasound may show a non-mobile defect in the gallbladder lumen which does not exhibit an associated acoustic shadow. Option: C. Diverticulosis of the gallbladder is usually manifest as black pigment stones impacted in the outpouchings of the lacunae of Luschka. Diverticulosis of the gallbladder may be demonstrated by cholecystography, especially when the gallbladder contracts after a fatty meal. Option: D. Adenomyomatosis : A polyp of the mucous membrane is fleshy and granulomatous. All layers of the gallbladder wall may be thickened, but sometimes an incomplete septum forms that separate the hyperplastic from the normal.

questions.text: A patient presents with gallstone ileus. The most commonly affected site is the?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Terminal ileum Dynamic bowel obstruction occurs because of gall stone. Mc site - terminal 60 cm of ileum/distal ileum C/f Pneumobilia Features of small Intestine obstruction Ectopic gall stone

Highyeild:

Gallstone ileus Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis where gallstones become impacted in the GI tract. It is more common in elderly individuals and women. Acute cholecystitis can lead to the erosion of inflamed tissues, resulting in a cholecystointestinal fistula . Small gallstones usually pass through the intestines on their own, but gallstones 2-5 cm in size may become stuck , particularly at the terminal ileum or ileocecal valve due to the narrow lumen and less active peristalsis. Symptoms may include acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of partial or complete gastrointestinal obstruction, dehydration, abdominal distension, tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice. Diagnostic methods include a plain abdominal radiograph, CT, and USG.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B & D. Jejunum, CBD, Colon are not the most common site for gallstone ileus.

Extraedge:

CT is considered superior to plain radiographs or USG, with a sensitivity of up to 93%. The most common surgical procedure for gallstone ileus is enterolithotomy , where a longitudinal incision is made on the antimesenteric border proximal to the site of gallstone impaction. A cholecystoenteric fistula should only be resected if the patient is stable and there are residual gallstones that may cause infection or recurrent ileus.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male comes to the OPD with yellowish discolouration of his skin and sclera. He says he has to itch over her body. She also has features of acute pancreatitis. On USG's abdomen dilatation of the common bile duct is seen. The physician suspects a gallstone impacted at the ampulla of Vater. Which of the following is the best investigation that can be done on this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ERCP This technique remains widely used as both a diagnostic and a therapeutic modality. Using a side-viewing endoscope the ampulla of Vater can be identified and cannulated. Injection of water-soluble contrast directly into the bile duct provides excellent images of the ductal anatomy.

Highyeild:

ERCP is effective in diagnosing choledocholithiasis. Experienced operators can achieve successful cannulation of the ampulla of Vater and diagnostic cholangiography in over 90% of cases. Due to the risks associated with the procedure, ERCP is rarely used as a purely diagnostic modality and is usually reserved for cases where therapeutic intervention is planned. Endoscopic ultrasound is a comparable alternative to ERCP in detecting common bile duct stones, with a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 97%. Endoscopic ultrasound lacks therapeutic capabilities and requires specialized expertise, making it less desirable except in specific clinical scenarios. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) may be performed for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes in rare cases where endoscopic or surgical approaches are contraindicated.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Ultrasound is already done on this patient so no need to do it again. Option: C. Plain radiograph - ductal anatomy is not seen in this. Option: D. PTC - best visualization of the proximal biliary tract.

Extraedge:

ERCP can also collec t bile or pancreatic fluid and brushings from duct strictures to confirm the suspected diagnosis of carcinoma, and brush cytology taken from malignant strictures yields a positive diagnosis in 40-50% of patients. Additionally, ERCP allows for the placement of biliary and pancreatic stents.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

10% The skillfully taken plain radiograph of the gallbladder will show radiopaque gallstones in 10% of patients. Rarely, the centre of a stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure and this gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on a radiograph: the ‘Mercedes–Benz’ or ‘seagull’ sign. A plain X-ray may also show the rare cases of calcification of the gallbladder, a so-called ‘porcelain’ gallbladder. This is more commonly seen in computed tomography (CT).

Highyeild:

A plain radiograph can detect radio-opaque stones in 10% of cases. Calcification of the gallbladder, also known as " porcelain " gallbladder, can be seen on a radiograph. Emphysematous cholecystitis , characterized by gas in the gallbladder wall, can be visualized on a radiograph. Gas in the biliary tree may be present after endoscopic sphincterotomy or surgical anastomosis.

questions.text: False about Strasberg’s classification of postoperative bile duct strictures is

options.label: C
options.text: E5 involves injury to aberrant duct and common hepatic duct

questions.correct_answer: A. E1 and E2 involves bifurcation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E1 and E2 involves bifurcation Among postoperative bile duct strictures, types E1 and E2 involve the common hepatic duct but not the bifurcation , with type E1 maintaining more than 2 cm of common hepatic duct below the bifurcation Type E2 is within 2 cm of the confluence. Type E3 strictures occur at the confluence, preserving the extrahepatic ducts, For Type E4 , the stricturing process includes the extrahepatic biliary tree. Type E5 strictures involve aberrant right hepatic duct anatomy, with injury to the aberrant duct and common hepatic duct. Strasberg's Classification of bile duct injuries is determined by the location of the injury and helps guide later surgical reconstruction.

Highyeild:

Strasberg Classification of bile duct injuries The classification is used to categorize laparoscopic biliary injuries . Type A involves bile leaks from minor ducts that are still in continuity with the common bile duct (CBD), and is the most common cause of biliary leaks after laparoscopic cholecystectomy. This type includes leakage from the cystic duct stump and a sub-vesical duct of Luschka. Type B involves the occlusion of a part of the biliary tree, usually an aberrant right sectoral duct. Type C is characterized by transection without ligation of an aberrant right sectoral duct. Type D involves a lateral injury to an extrahepatic duct. Type E includes biliary strictures and is further divided into E1 to E5 based on Bismuth's classification.

Random:

Explanation For Other Options:- Options: B & C. These are correct statements.

questions.text: The most common site of Gall stone impaction in cholecysto-intestinal fistula is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Proximal to ileo-cecal junction Gallstone Ileus: Obstruction of the intestinal lumen from a gallstone carries the misnomer gallstone ileus, which is, in fact, a mechanical blockage. In order for a stone of sufficient size to obstruct the intestine, a large stone in the dependent portion of the gallbladder that has fistulized into the adjacent duodenum passes directly into the intestine. Most of these fistulas occur in older patients and may be caused by inflammation in the gallbladder or simply pressure necrosis. The most common site of stone impaction is in the distal ileum , a few centimetres proximal to the ileocecal valve, where the calibre of the ileum decreases.

Diagnostic methods include a plain abdominal radiograph, CT, and USG.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding HCC

options.label: A
options.text: Extrahepatic metastasis is a contraindication to resection

options.label: B
options.text: Low CTP score indicates increased postoperative morbidity and mortality

options.label: C
options.text: Intrahepatic recurrence occurs in around 50 % of cases within 5 years of resection

questions.correct_answer: A. Extrahepatic metastasis is a contraindication to resection
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extrahepatic metastasis is a contraindication to resection In general, oncological contraindications to resection now include:Extrahepatic metastasis;Multiple and bilobar tumours;Involvement of the main bile duct; andPresence of tumour thrombus in the main portal vein/vena cava.

Highyeild:

Hepatocellular Carcinoma Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) is the most common solid organ cancer and is responsible for a significant number of deaths in patients with cirrhosis. Individuals with HBV infection have a 100-fold increased risk of developing HCC. HCC is more common in males , and 60-90% of cases arise in cirrhotic liver , with post-necrotic cirrhosis having the highest risk of developing into HCC. HCC has a strong propensity for invasion of vascular channels . The most common symptom of HCC is abdominal pain , followed by weight loss. Significant weight loss is defined as 5% in 1 month, 10% in 6 months, or 20% in 1 year. HCC usually presents at a late stage, and symptoms at an advanced stage are vague, including non-specific symptoms such as anorexia and hepatomegaly . Paraneoplastic syndromes that can occur in HCC include hypercholesterolemia, hypoglycemia, erythrocytosis, hypercalcemia, vascular bruit, GI bleeding, tumour rupture, jaundice due to biliary obstruction, and paraneoplastic syndrome. Tumor markers for HCC include PIVKA , glypican-3 , AFP fractions , and AFP-L3 . The serum AFP level is elevated in over 70% of patients with HCC. Diagnosis of HCC is based on non-invasive criteria, including focal lesion 1-2 cm with two imaging techniques showing arterial hypervascularization and venous washout , and focal lesion >2 cm with one imaging technique showing arterial hypervascularization and venous washout . Techniques used for diagnosis include dynamic CT and MRI. Screening for HCC is done through regular ultrasound scanning in high-risk populations. Biopsy proof of HCC is not required for diagnosis. The only treatment modality with curative potential is complete excision by partial hepatectomy or by total hepatectomy and transplant.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Postoperative morbidity and mortality are known to increase with a higher CTP score, and major liver resection is generally only considered feasible in patients with CTPA disease. Option: C. Intrahepatic recurrence occurs in around 80% of cases within 5 years of resection Option: D. All of the above cannot be the answer

Extraedge:

Extrahepatic metastasis is a contraindication to resection In general, oncological contraindications to resection now include: extrahepatic metastasis; multiple and bilobar tumours; involvement of the main bile duct; and presence of tumour thrombus in the main portal vein/vena cava.

questions.text: All are true about hepatic adenoma Except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

90 % develops into hepatocellular carcinoma Hepatic adenoma: Adenomas are benign liver tumours seen almost exclusively in women aged between 25 and 50 years. These well-defined and vascular lesions are classically associated with the use of the oral contraceptive pill and are generally solitary. The majority are found incidentally on imaging, although up to one-third may present with pain because of rupture or bleeding. Adenomas are recognised as having malignant potential, with up to 10% developing into hepatocellular carcinoma. The risk of rupture and malignancy means that surgical excision is generally recommended if >5 cm in size, although some lesions may regress after discontinuation of the oral contraceptive pill.

Highyeild:

Adenomas are benign liver tumours that occur mostly in women aged between 25 and 50 years. They are typically well-defined and highly vascular lesions that are often associated with the use of oral contraceptive pills. Adenomas are usually solitary and can be discovered incidentally during imaging tests, but up to one-third may present with pain due to rupture or bleeding. Adenomas have the potential to become malignant, with up to 10% of cases developing into hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Random:

Explanation For Other Options:- Options: A, B & D. All are true statements.

Extraedge:

Surgical removal is generally recommended for adenomas larger than 5 cm due to the risk of rupture and malignancy. In some cases, adenomas may regress after discontinuation of oral contraceptive pills.
